articles.headline: Facing Down the Bankers
articles.snippet: Dennis Kelleher, who built a reputation cleaning up after crises, runs Better Markets, a nonprofit that pushes for tighter regulation of American banks.
articles.abstract: Dennis Kelleher, who built a reputation cleaning up after crises, runs Better Markets, a nonprofit that pushes for tighter regulation of American banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sitting in a corner office high above K Street here, Dennis M. Kelleher, one of the most powerful lobbyists on financial regulatory reform, looks every bit the corporate lawyer and high-ranking Senate aide he formerly was: tailored suit, quick smile, assertive tone.

articles.headline: Europe Fears Bailout of Spain Would Strain Its Resources
articles.snippet: With a bailout of Spain becoming a more distinct possibility, European policy makers are questioning who will provide the money that Madrid needs to stay in business.
articles.abstract: With a bailout of Spain becoming a more distinct possibility, European policy makers are questioning who will provide the money that Madrid needs to stay in business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Spain’s deepening financial problems make a European bailout a more distinct possibility, a looming question is where the money will come from.

articles.headline: Samsung Takes On iPod Touch, With Flair
articles.snippet: The Samsung Galaxy Player 4.2 is the best in its family, and has much to like in a more open and expandable machine than the iPod Touch.
articles.abstract: The Samsung Galaxy Player 4.2 is the best in its family, and has much to like in a more open and expandable machine than the iPod Touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the swimming pool’s worth of ink that has been spilled on Apple over the years, not enough fuss has been made about the iPod Touch.

articles.headline: Daddy, What Were Compact Discs?
articles.snippet: A reporter imagines when the world will be completely wireless and digital and how much the products will cost.
articles.abstract: A reporter imagines when the world will be completely wireless and digital and how much the products will cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE day, when my children are a little older, I will gather them close and I will tell them about how I lived through the Great Format Wars.

articles.headline: For the White House, a Wary Wait as Syria Boils
articles.snippet: President Obama is loath to engage in new military actions, but with each passing incident, the scale of the crisis in Syria grows.
articles.abstract: President Obama is loath to engage in new military actions, but with each passing incident, the scale of the crisis in Syria grows.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After ordering American forces to Libya last year, President Obama declared that he had tackled a humanitarian crisis more decisively than his predecessors.

articles.headline: On Campus, New Deals With Banks
articles.snippet: A report finds new connections between colleges trying to recoup budget cuts and financial institutions seeking new customers.
articles.abstract: A report finds new connections between colleges trying to recoup budget cuts and financial institutions seeking new customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: College campuses have long been attractive hunting grounds for financial institutions looking for new customers.

articles.headline: Researchers Find Clues in Malware
articles.snippet: Researchers said they believe the Flame computer virus came from different programmers but the same, state-sponsored campaign that damaged Iran’s nuclear program in 2010.
articles.abstract: Researchers said they believe the Flame computer virus came from different programmers but the same, state-sponsored campaign that damaged Iran’s nuclear program in 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Security experts have only begun examining the thousands of lines of code that make up Flame, an extensive, data-mining computer virus that has been designed to steal information from computers across the Middle East, but already digital clues point to its creators and capabilities.

articles.headline: A Terse Warning for Euro States: Do Something Now
articles.snippet: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, told members of the European Parliament that now it was up to their leaders to save the euro.
articles.abstract: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, told members of the European Parliament that now it was up to their leaders to save the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president who pulled the Continent back from the financial brink late last year, is facing an even more daunting challenge as the debt crisis in Spain deepens. But this time, he may have a harder time fashioning a rescue plan that will work.
